Fallout 4's 'Far Harbor' DLC is much of the same, but still incredibly addictive

May 25, 2016

For me Fallout 4 was a game that, despite the hype that was built up around its release, didnâ€™t astound me, nor disappoint. Some of the pieces were there: an expansive world full of characters each with their own backstories and motives, an immersive storyline with plot twists at every turn and weapon and armor mods galore, but often the gameâ€™s negatives outweighed its redeeming qualities: frequent crashes causing players to lose progress, repetitive side quests with no end in sight and enemies with ridiculously better equipment and/or strength.

Thereâ€™s no denying though, Fallout 4 definitely had its moments. In a nostalgic way, that I sometimes look back on the games Iâ€™ve played with, I replay the adventures I had with Nick Valentine in my head with a sort of sentimentality that I donâ€™t feel with other games. Itâ€™s probably for this reason that, despite all the failings the original game had, I decided to give Bethesdaâ€™s new â€˜Far Harborâ€™ DLC a go.

You'll still find beautifully-lit, detailed environments in Far Harbor's chaotic wasteland.

You'll still find beautifully-lit, detailed environments in Far Harbor's chaotic wasteland.

After checking on the home screen under â€˜add-onsâ€™ that itâ€™s installed we can start. While beginning as a missing child case taken on by Valentineâ€™s Detective Agency in Diamond City, Far Harborâ€™s story evolves into one that echoes other Fallout games - a conflict between warring factions that our character inevitably becomes a part of. There are the Children of Atom, worshippers of a religion built around the dropping of the atomic bomb (whom weâ€™ve met before), Acadia a population of synths (or humans) undergoing identity crises and of course residents of Far Harbor, a population clinging on to remnants of a once established island.

"Far Harbor very cleverly plays on the concept of a synth's place in society, a theme that's been core to Fallout 4 throughout."

If you enjoyed the complex decision-making that Fallout 4â€™s central narrative thrusted players into, thereâ€™s no shortage in Far Harbor. How your own characterâ€™s story pans out is entirely dependent upon his or her own sense of identity and values. Is there such a thing as the â€˜greater goodâ€™? Can you make the necessary sacrifices to survive? Far Harbor also very cleverly plays on the concept of a synthâ€™s place in society, a theme thatâ€™s been core to Fallout 4 throughout. It couldnâ€™t more perfectly reflect our own society in which the possibility of free-thinking artificial intelligence is no longer science fiction.

About halfway through Far Harborâ€™s main missions, players are tasked with unlocking a characterâ€™s memories in an entirely self-contained Minecraft-like, Portal-esque puzzle game. Donâ€™t be surprised if this chapter in the story frustrates you. Fortunately Bethesda keeps the game mode challenging enough to hold oneâ€™s attention, and the audio snippets these â€˜memoriesâ€™ contain are gold. Critics have slammed these missions for detracting from the momentum of the main storyline, but I felt it broke things up nicely in the sense that I had to re-acquaint myself with the mechanics of the game once I eventually returned to the wasteland.

Side missions are a great way to explore Far Harbor's expansive terrain.

Side missions are a great way to explore Far Harbor's expansive terrain.

If youâ€™re aspiring to achieve 100% completion of â€˜Far Harborâ€™, Iâ€™d advise you clear your calendar for the next month. While itâ€™s possible to complete the main storyline within about 10 hours (other critics suggest 12, my experience differs), the Far Harbor DLC has no shortage of side missions and quests that lead to better loot and experience to spend on skills. If youâ€™re the investigative type, thereâ€™s a hilarious murder-mystery-style quest in the islandâ€™s only vault under the Cliffâ€™s Edge Hotel, but Far Harbor certainly wonâ€™t leave you short of anything to do. Completing the last â€˜memoryâ€™ puzzle discussed above also reveals the locations of military-grade weapons and armour on the map (in sequence) - very useful if you come up against any Mirlurks.

One of the great additions to Fallout 4 was the concept of companions, AI characters you can bring along for the ride. While Nick Valentineâ€™s depressive demeanour adds to the seriousness of the situation, â€˜Old Longfellowâ€™ a character you meet relatively early on, instilled a sense of confidence in me as I navigated the wasteland. Perhaps I have daddy issues, or Longfellowâ€™s shotgun is just more powerful than other charactersâ€™, but get into a heavy firefight and donâ€™t expect the old guy to stay up for long (no pun intended). In addition to Far Harborâ€™s companions, the DLC brings an array of weapons and customisations, although Iâ€™m certainly a big fan of the Harpoon Gun which I bought in Far Harbor itself. Expect to kill pesky Super Mutants in two (or sometimes one) shots as you watch metal bolts splatter their guts in slow motion.

I hadnâ€™t envisioned myself returning to the Fallout 4 universe, but if you already own the game Iâ€™d definitely recommend downloading a copy of Far Harbor. The mechanics of the game largely feel the same, but the DLCâ€™s slow burn and suspense forced me to want to find answers and commit time, not feel overwhelmed. Enjoy the ride.
